executive_summary: The Methanol Production industry produces the organic chemical, methanol, for uses in plastics, paints, and fuel. Methanol is primarily produced by reforming natural gas then converting and distilling the resulting gas yielding a clear, liquid, organic chemical. This makes production sensitive to changes in the price of natural gas. Industry operators produce methanol in use in consumer products, medical products, and fuel sectors. Key buying industries are driven by consumer demand, meaning consumer spending indirectly affects operators in this industry. As consumer demand rose in 2021 as the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic slowed down, so did demand from key buying industries. Moreover, an increase in global demand for methanol sharply increased the amount of industry exports, resulting in revenue growth despite lows experienced by the coronavirus. Revenue is estimated to increase an annualized 4.9% to $3.7 billion over the five years to 2022, including an increase of 3.7% in 2022.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Operators in the Methanol Production industry are primarily involved in the production of methanol for use in energy applications.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry operators can derive methanol from natural gas, coal, and biomass and renewable sources. Due to natural gas being the most economical derivative for methanol production, this product is estimated to account for 64.4% of revenue. This makes production sensitive to changes in the price of natural gas.

Methanol has seen increased applications as an alternative fuel, especially overseas. Starting in 2015 and continuing into the current period, exports have steadily increased as a share of revenue. An increased trade prevalence puts industry operators at risk.

Due to the high reliance of natural gas in the production of methanol, industry revenue and profit is highly sensitive to the price of natural gas. Additionally, as an alternative fuel, the price of methanol is correlated with the world price of crude oil.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is expected to remain highly commoditized over the next five years. The most economical component in which methanol is derived from is anticipated to remain natural gas.
Due to the breakout of exports for industry operators in 2015, the value of exports is projected to experience meager growth in the outlook period.
The average industry profit margin is expected to remain steady over the next five years.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry produce methanol, which is a clear, biodegradable liquid commodity chemical that is a key ingredient in a variety of chemical derivatives.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: Volatility in the price of natural gas as well as other fuel commodities resulted in fluctuating industry revenue
Rising input costs can lead to a higher price of the product, as operators push the increased costs toward buyers
Despite increasing profit, it is projected that no new entrants will enter the industry over the five years to 2022
Volatility in commodity prices is estimated to decrease, which is anticipated to lead to a decrease in the price of methanol
Due to the breakout of exports for industry operators in 2015, the value of exports is projected to experience meager growth in the outlook period
Lower restrictions will enable industry operators to increase operating capacity
The Methanol Production industry is highly concentrated and globalized, with only a handful of domestic manufacturers

market_segmentation.segment_description: Methanol is used as an intermediate material to manufacture products like acrylic plastics, synthetic fabrics, adhesives and paints.
Companies in this sector use methanol to produce fuel additives like MTBE and DME, and as a fuel for vehicles and ships.
The US has grown significantly as a methanol exporter over the five years to 2022 due to increased production capacity.
Other markets use methanol to produce plywood for construction and as a chemical agent in pharmaceuticals and agrichemicals.

products_and_services.product_description: Methanol derived from natural gas is the most popular way to produce methanol. In 2022, an estimated 64.4% of the total methanol produced is created by using natural gas as a feedstock.
The second-most popular way to produce methanol is by using coal as a feedstock. This method accounts for 34.6% of methanol production in 2022.
Methanol derived from biomasses and other renewable sources accounts for only 1.0% of total production in 2022.

tier_2_suppliers: Natural Gas Distribution in the US
tier_1_buyers: Plastic Products Miscellaneous Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for methanol production depends on demand for transport fuels as methanol is used to fuel internal combustion engines and as a diesel substitute.
Methanol is commonly converted into formaldehyde, which is used in manufacturing plastics, plywood, paints, explosives and textiles.
The COVID-19 pandemic caused a slump in global fuel prices and declining supply of manufactured goods, lowering methanol prices in 2020.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports have slowed as domestic manufacturing increased, satisfying 25.6% of demand in 2022, down from 26.4% in 2017.
Exports have grown sharply, accounting for 25.7% of revenue in 2022, up from 13.4% in 2017, driven by demand for alternative fuels.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest concentration of methanol production establishments at 26.9% in 2022, due to proximity to feedstock suppliers.
The Southwest region accounts for 19.2% of industry establishments in 2022, being located near feedstock suppliers.
The Great Lakes region has 16.5% of methanol production establishments in 2022 due to its industrial regions.
The Mid-Atlantic region is the fourth largest with 14.2% of industry establishments in 2022.

regulations_points.regulation_description: In the US, ASTM D 4814-10a limits methanol up to 0.3% by volume or up to 2.75% by volume with an equal volume of butanol, or higher molecular weight alcohol.
US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) waivers under the substantially similar rule permit methanol levels higher than ASTM D4814-10a.
The EPA determines the annual percentage standards for renewable fuels that obligated parties must comply with under the Renewable Fuel Standard program.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, making it difficult for new entrants.
The industry has very high revenue volatility.
The industry has high capital intensity requirements.
The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance.

factors_decreased_barrier.description: The industry has light and steady regulation levels.
The industry has low levels of technology change.

basis_points.basis_description: Internal competition is moderate based on price, raw material costs, production efficiency, customer reach, reputation, service quality, regulatory compliance, and economies of scale.
Major external competition is expected from increased demand for hybrid and electric vehicles.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top three players account for 44.7% of industry revenue in 2022.
Industry concentration has remained relatively stable over the five years to 2022 due to few changes in production facilities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Major costs include transportation of products.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The conversion and distilling process to yield methanol requires large plant and equipment's to successfully operate at a profitable scale.
Plants tend to be highly automated, requiring limited on-site labor.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue have historically reacted sharply to shifts in global energy markets.
Since industry goods are used by consumers and fuel sectors alike, the health of these markets determines industry prosperity.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Most technological developments being aimed toward increasing the efficiency of the production process.
Production technologies are rarely drastically changed due to the high costs associated with revamping a production plant.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports have risen slightly over the past five years but are beginning to occupy a lower share of overall domestic demand.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Due to the wide range of applications for methanol, it is not uncommon for operators to produce various methanol products.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years? Did that change during 2021?
FAQs.answer: Methanol is primarily produced by natural gas. The price of natural gas has historically been volatile, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the world?
FAQs.answer: The spike in demand for methanol products in 2021 caused wage increases as more employees were needed to meet said demand.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Although automation has increased, average wages have also risen due to demand for methanol products.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Technology has remained stagnant, with improvements in production efficiency becoming the differentiating factor.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Larger operators have departments to comply with several state and national regulations.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently? Did your company receive assistance from the CARES Act?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory costs remain high due to a shift towards a more environmentally friendly process.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins in the industry have increased over the past five years due to higher exports.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects on the horizon that will require capital financing?
FAQs.answer: Capital intensity has remained stable, requiring high amounts of capital to operate.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to members? Do you have fixed, long-term supply contracts with upstream input suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Any increase in input costs can reflect in the cost of methanol.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to operate near optimum capacity?
FAQs.answer: Yes, our operations have maintained near-optimum capacity.

FAQs.question: How has the COVID-19 pandemic affected operations?
FAQs.answer: CDC guidelines have reduced production capacity, impacting time to produce industry products.

FAQs.question: Does international trade play a significant role in your company's operations? Do you track changes in the trade-weighted index?
FAQs.answer: As the US dollar weakens, our industry sees an increase in exports.

FAQs.question: How will the decreasing price of natural gas affect your production? What percent of your company's sales are connected to the production of methane with natural gas?
FAQs.answer: Production is sensitive to natural gas prices. Any increase will likely affect sales negatively.
